name: Glasgow
fun_fact: Fun fact: Glasgow only received its first Michelin star in 2021, but by 2025 the city has two Michelin-starred restaurants and multiple Bib Gourmand winners - proving that Scotland's culinary revolution is happening faster in gritty, creative Glasgow than in refined Edinburgh.

hero_dishes.name: Haggis, Neeps, and Tatties
hero_dishes.description: Scotland's national dish - sheep's stomach stuffed with oats, onions, and offal, served with mashed turnips and potatoes
hero_dishes.origin_story: Immortalized by Robert Burns, haggis is Scotland's most iconic dish. Despite its intimidating description, it's savory, peppery, and delicious. At Stravaigin, they've perfected the traditional preparation
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Stravaigin (Gibson Street - excellent version), Mharsanta (haggis lasagne variation), Rab Ha's (Scottish small plates)

hero_dishes.name: Cullen Skink
hero_dishes.description: Thick Scottish soup made with smoked haddock, onions, leeks, and potatoes - creamy, smoky, and warming
hero_dishes.origin_story: Originating in the coastal town of Cullen, this soup has become a Scottish staple. Glasgow's seafood restaurants make it with the freshest smoked haddock
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Crabshakk (Argyle Street), CafÃ© Gandolfi (Albion Street - truly delicious recipe)

hero_dishes.name: Scottish Seafood at The Finnieston
hero_dishes.description: Sustainable Scottish seafood including Loch Fyne langoustines, Shetland hake, and fresh oysters from local waters
hero_dishes.origin_story: The Finnieston celebrates Scotland's incredible seafood with a regularly changing seasonal menu. Their commitment to sustainability and showcasing Scotland's waters has made them a Glasgow institution

hero_dishes.name: Modern Scottish Fine Dining at The Gannet
hero_dishes.description: Ambitious, inventive dishes centered around Scotland's larder - think venison with foraged mushrooms or Orkney scallops with peas
hero_dishes.origin_story: This Michelin-rated Finnieston hotspot represents Glasgow's new culinary confidence - using Scotland's incredible ingredients with creativity and technical skill
hero_dishes.where_to_find: The Gannet (Finnieston - Michelin-rated), Number 16 (West End - Michelin Guide recognition)

signature_drinks.name: Scotch Whisky
signature_drinks.description: Single malt whisky from Scotland's distilleries - smoky, complex, and sacred
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Sipped neat or with a splash of water at pubs. Glasgow has excellent whisky bars where bartenders guide you through regional differences. Never ask for ice

signature_drinks.name: Irn-Bru
signature_drinks.description: Scotland's other national drink - bright orange, impossibly sweet soda made from a secret recipe
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Consumed as a hangover cure, with fish and chips, or straight from the can. Glaswegians are fiercely loyal to this Scottish soft drink
